title: Architecture vs. Politics
segmentation: Good evening everybody.
I'm 1/4 as you just heard from TEP.
First of all, thank you for inviting us here and we are group of four people.
Coming from different parts of Europe.
Charlie is from Corsica Philip from Luxembourg, and studies grew up in Lower Austria and I'm from Salzburg, we.
Come from different parts or from different countries, but we consider ourselves as Europeans.
Now all being based in Vienna in the middle of Europe and as.
We know.
Still has in history with nationalism, right wing parties and separation, which is also in affecting our current present.
And as we start.
I did too.
Working our first project, which was actually about embassies having these ideologies in mind, we started to ask ourselves what's the real meaning of an embassy?
What could an embassy stand for and how can it affect actually so?
It is basically.
They are to unify the relations between different countries.

And Interestingly, the German word for Embassy Botschaft also means message, so we turned away from the embassy of being an actual architectural building and fire if more further fit more as in concept for an transboundary message that could be spread about borders.
During that.
It was around like the end of 2015.
We were facing a lot of political issues like the refugee crisis.
The reaction of certain borders in Europe.
Of course, the uprising of right wing ideology and separation.
And so.
We thought what could be a message for an already crumbling Europe?
It's really looked like it is already happening and.
And we could feel it in Vienna, especially with all the people going through.
And of course, as you know, now we have an elected right wing or right from the middle conservative conservative political agenda going on.
And as we were observing these things, the concept started to make more and more sense and to evolve.
So we came up with the concept for.
Or possible future of the European Union or the OR Europe in its whole.
And we called it the goal.
Nature of nothing.
The Golden age of Nothing is a dystopian book.
Which shows a possible future.
Which is a possible worst future from our point of view?
The book tells about separated states.
Where nationalism, segregation and the fear of the unknown have taken over.
Each of the 19 chapters is told by a specific resident, which is trapped in one of these newly created states.
While reading those short stories written in a very personal way.
The reader gets an inside about the Topa graphical and political situation of these characters and their landscapes they're living in.
Um, as architects.
We didn't only want to tell stories, but we wanted to use the tools and the languages that.
We what we do in our order that we use in our daily or on our daily basis.
So therefore the stories are combined by these images of that old scenarios.
The combination of images and texts about people's everyday habits close to the borders.
And the critical view on the oppressive state should invite the reader to inside his or her thoughts by asking 20.
The people to translate the text in the mother tongues and I side effect secured we already created.
Kind of a network that spreads across Europe and in a way it connects and builds up on the European idea of solidarity and unity.
The Golden age of nothing.
Bing was a project as well that was working more on a global or international basis, but with other.
Checked, we focused more on some certain political topics in.
Recollect space we had.
We worked closely with refugees and we tried to focus on the places or some special places in their Homeland that they have to leave behind.
Um?
We
We created some.
They they gave us a story and we worked with that story about this one place or this particular base that they.
We felt sorry to leave behind and in a simple way.
We recreated it and.
We tried to keep the graphics very basic so that the viewer could also reflect and rethink the store that old stories.
And get an insight about what people actually had to leave behind.
But we also try.
Right to focus on people, not only far away in this project.
It is, it is about a particular place or public space in Vienna.
Which had some ongoing architectural debate, and it didn't really workout.
So we created a simple interactive game.
Beam Interactive architectural game which actually used the already existing arm objects of this place and gave the players the possibility to redesign or play with scenarios for these spaces.
So in the simple way we showed some possibilities that are closer to the user and really reflect the needs of some users.
So.
The next project actually works with what is what.
What happens when an user really takes over public place?

The we started to observe some public spaces and its users and we focused on the illegal or similar use of those spaces and how people adapt to certain architectural environments, especially squares or riches ETC for their own some.
So it was a huge exhibition and and there was.
Some topics, for example like squatting.
What would happen if there would be actually a side where you can?
Find all the squads like in real estate site and could.
Could get to know where these things happen and actually could use them as normal settlements.
Um?
Then something's not working.
Another part, sorry another part was homelessness where we had our focus on how homeless people actually use.
And.
Take part in creating their spaces in the public and deferred or another part was protests.
It was interesting how police and also protesters use streets or certain cityscapes so that they can.
Protect themselves or protect others.
I don't know, sorry.
OK, I would just continue without the presentation.
It's not that much anymore.

Yeah, this was some political projects that we tried to criticise some certain agendas that exist in our society, but we also take part in some idea competition as normal architectural competitions in which we.
Try to continue to challenge ourselves to not only do these observing or theoretical or conceptual things, but also try to take in.
What we do and create actually actually real build architecture.
None of it got built, but it's at least some ideas.
Um?
This one.
This was a project which focused on non places and.
That's the second project which actually took a focus on our daily habits, like we separated daily, written in a in three parts, which is like 8 hours work 8 hours sleep and eight hours leisure.
So I hope you can see that.
Or maybe it's a bit.
Understandable what we try to do and what we try to take also in our architectural projects.
And yeah, that's that's it.
Then thank you.
And if there are some questions we are.
